title: 106_hr5664
content: The Act is titled the "Voters' Bill of Rights for the 21st Century" and Congress acknowledges the rights of American voters. The "Voters' Bill of Rights for the 21st Century" outlines key rights for American voters, including clear ballot formats, fair technology for candidate selection, protection from media influence, freedom from intimidation, timely counting of absentee votes, and uniform statewide voting standards. The "Voters' Bill of Rights for the 21st Century" includes rights such as a uniform statewide standard for counting votes, an Electoral College reflecting voter preferences, fair resolution of election complaints, voting on a day maximizing turnout, and making informed decisions on Election Day. Established is the 21st Century Bipartisan Electoral Commission to protect and enforce voting rights. Membership and appointment details are outlined. The 21st Century Bipartisan Electoral Commission consists of 20 members appointed by various leaders, with specific qualifications and restrictions on the number of elected officials and government employees. The 21st Century Bipartisan Electoral Commission consists of 20 members appointed by leaders, with qualifications in election laws, the Constitution, voting rights, and technology. Efforts are made to ensure diverse representation. The 21st Century Bipartisan Electoral Commission consists of 20 members appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment for life. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The members elect a chair and vice chair from different political parties. Meetings and hearings are scheduled by the chair in consultation with the vice chair. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions. SEC. 103. DUTIES. The Commission's duties include developing a clear and user-friendly ballot format for Presidential elections, evaluating voting technologies for accuracy, and making recommendations to Congress for a Federal matching grant program to improve voting systems. The Commission will recommend voter identification methods to ensure accurate recognition without intimidation, establish military and civilian absentee ballot standards for timely counting on Election Day. The Commission will make recommendations on poll closing times, changing Election Day to increase voter participation, reassessing the electoral college, and evaluating strategies for electing the President and Vice President in the 21st century. They will also examine State laws related to elections. The Commission will examine State laws to determine if there is a uniform statewide standard for vote tabulation and make recommendations on conducting a 21st Century Voter Education Campaign. They will seek guidance from governors and election officials. SEC. 104. FINAL REPORT. The Commission must submit a final report to the President and Congress within 24 months of its initial meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for addressing identified problems. Any member can include additional views in the report. SEC. 105. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. They can take testimony and evidence as needed to fulfill the requirements of the Act. Additionally, the Commission can request information directly from federal departments and agencies to carry out the provisions of the Act. SEC. 106 of the Act addresses Commission personnel matters. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The chairperson can appoint staff, request Federal employee details, and hire an executive director with Commission approval. Pay for personnel cannot exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will establish a website for public participation. It will terminate within 30 days of submitting its final report. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Commission for the first 3 fiscal years. Congress supports a voluntary agreement on election reporting by media. Congress encourages broadcasters and media to strengthen their participation in the voluntary agreement on election reporting outlined in a specific report from 1989.
